bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Kenneth F. Maxcy, August 30, 1923

div1.p: Carter responds to questions from Maxcy regarding the blood index of malaria and problems with blood examination tests based on data from various scientists addressing these issues.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Kanneth F. Maxcy, August 30, 1923
div1.opener:
(Copy)
PERSONAL
/L C
Badin Hospital,
Badin, N.C.
August 30, 1923.
Dr Kenneth F. Maxcy,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Care of State Health Officer,
Montgomery, Ala.
Dear Doctor Maxcy:
div1.p:
About the problem in relation to the blood index
of malaria about which you asked, I had purposed to wait until I
got back home, where I have access to notes etc., but as I am still
in bed I will outline it to you as well as I can without notes
and send you a supplementary letter when I get to Washington,
which I think will be shortly.
The problem was:

(1) To determine what proportion of infections would
be missed by a blood examination (thick film) by a careful and
trained man on a single examination.

(2) What proportion of cases found positive by such
examination in the late fall would be found negative (presumably,
but not necessarily, cured spontaneously) in the spring or
summer under the ordinary conditions of life in the country on
plantations in the south. The “ordinary conditions of life”
do not imply the exclusion of quinine or its efficient use --
simply people living as they habitually live during the fall,
winter and spring.
Let me take the second problem first:

The desirability of its solution -- or rather the
solution of the inverse problem: the proportion of relapses
(parasitic or symptomatic) is stressed by Ross in his “Prevention of
Malaria”.

A good deal of work on it has been done by the Italians,-
especially by Cacini and by Sella. Ross himself gives data on
this problem from India and Bass has data on it in his work on the
Yazoo, where, however -- judging partly by the statistics of Taylor
in Arkansas and my own single observation at Wilson, - his proportion
of relapses is too high. My recollection is that he found from a
little over 50% to about 69% relapses among the people who had
malaria in 1918: but you have access to his papers.

-2-
This problem was taken up tentatively by us in 1914.
It was planned to take a careful blood index of a badly infected
community after the date at which infection could be contracted,
taking the names of all persons. To take the same index by the
same man -- or one equally careful and skillful -- in the early
Spring before malaria could be contracted. A comparison of these
would give us data upon the subject. For instance, if 20% of all
those that were positive in the fall showed negative in the spring
and continued to show negative until well into the malaria season,
it would be evidence -- although not quite proof -- that that
proportion, under the conditions that existed, had freed themselves
from infection. I say “not quite proof” because for proof
these people should be kept not exposed to malaria infection and
watched a long time. On the other hand, if 20% of those found
negative in the fall were found positive in the early spring before
it was possible to contract malaria, it would be proof (not merely
evidence) that 20% at least of infections had been missed on our
suppossedly careful examination. I say “at least” because it is
obvious that if a careful examination in the late fall missed
finding some infections a similar careful examination in the early
spring might do the same and 20% would not represent all the
infections beyond those found in the fall that existed. This
difficulty could be met, however, by keeping our men who were
negative in the fall out of contact with infected Anopheles
for a considerable time until we could be certain by further
examinations that no parasites could be found in their blood.

For the early spring chances of exposure to infected Anopheles
we must take into consideration the hibernated females which --
in any district we have examined in the United States -- are indeed
come through the winter uninfected, but which, if they enter houses,
(as quads do) can readily become infected from carriers, in whom,
of course, the parasite does winter and, it being warm in the house,
at the end of 20 or 30 days infect other men.

This matter has never been worked out in America but frankly
I am inclined to think that a considerable number of the early
spring cases are infections by these hibernated females becoming
thus infected in houses and staying in houses or maybe warm stables
long enough to become infective. This, of course, could happen before
the flight of the earliest spring brood who have no houses to warm up in.

Angus MacDonald has laid some stress on this in the early spring
post-bellum malaria in England.

Dr. von Ezdorf took a blood index (thick film) at Scott, Miss.
in the fall of 1915. At my instance, Mayne took a similar index
there in February 1915 in conjunction with his great work on the
hibernation of the parasite in the mosquito. As I remember the
figures ----(my memory is quite reliable, but I will send the exact
data when I get home) --- von Ezdorf out of 1666 people found a
positive blood index of 41.11%. Mayne on 1164 specimens found an
index of 39.9% (or 39.5%). Both were careful men: both used the
same method in getting the specimens and in examining them: both
took a sufficient number of specimens to eliminate accidental errors
of observation: both found approximately the same proportion of
-3-
of positives. If then there was no chance of new infections
in the interval between these indices one must take one horn or
the other of this dilemma.

(a) either the men that were positive in the fall were
positive in the spring and those that were negative in the fall
were negative in the spring or

(b) that equal numbers changed from negative to positive
and from positive to negative.

In only a small number -- 103 is my recollection --
were specimens taken from the same men whose names were recorded
by von Ezdorf as positive --- he kept no record of his negative
cases. Of these 103, 55, as I remember, Mayne found negative
(53%). Now 103 is not enough to make a percentage on, but
if this proportion held true of other positives turning to
negatives we will have to accept (b) as our explanation of the
result of these observations.

Mayne's index was certainly made before the spring
flight of Anopheles. His own dissections of wild Anopheles satisfy
me that it was made before the hibernated ones became infective.
I am not, however, certain that von Ezdorf's index was taken after
all reasonable probability of infection was passed. (I will send
you the dates when I get home).

I made several attempts with Mayne at the rural units
of the penitentiaries of Louisiana and Mississippi to repeat this
experiment, recording the names, and had the dates which would
be beyond dispute, yet the positive data was so small that, while
I have it, it is not enough to draw conclusions from.

I did send to the Central Office, however, -- in 1917
as I recollect -- a rather long-winded equation by which --
(admitting certain postulates, which I confess are only approximately
correct) -- one can, from a few satisfactory observations of this
kind, determine the proportions of infections that are missed at a
careful examination by the method used and therefore the factor
by which this positive finding must be multiplied to get approximately
a true infection rate from such a blood index. It is rather an
intricate equation, but not especially so. Certainly not any more
so than the one Ross gives for the increase and diminution of
malaria with the increase and diminution of the number of Anopheles
present. At any rate, it is not in the same class with Pearl's
(Lottka's) transcendental equation developing Ross', which while I could
followI I would never reccomend to any friend as light reading.

I think I have a copy of it at home. Whether it is
worth undertaking, even incidentally, any observation of this sort,
naturally the central Office must be the judge. It is at least
a question and depends upon what other work you are doing, but it
is connate to the work that you and others have been doing the last
two seasons in the malaria index and is the problem you referred to.

-4-
I will ask you then to please send this letter to
Dr. Fricks. I would send a copy, as is my usual custom,
but the typewriter (the machine,-not Laura) is old and out of
order and refuses to copy. Indeed, I expect you will find
some script in this letter.

closer.seg:
P.S. I have 2 records about the Scott observations - in a
note book - but I will go back to the original sources
and send them to you when I get back to Washington.
Also will give you the title and Journal containing a
beautiful article on the relation of the blood index to
the splenic index in Batavia, by, as I recollect, the two
Swellengrebles ans Schüffner,-which you can get from the
Bureau. This in re Veldee's recent paper of splenic index
in Missouri.
H.R.C.
